awd_titl_txt: The Final Hour of a Massive Star:  Silicon Shell Burning and the Subsequent Supernova
awd_abstract_narration:
The final stage of life for a massive star (larger than about nine times the mass of the Sun) is the nuclear fusion ("burning") of silicon (SiSB) to create iron in a shell around an inert iron core, increasing the mass of the iron core.  This stage can last up to an hour until growth of the iron core triggers its collapse to a compact and dense neutron star (NS) surrounded by accreting material.  Subatomic particles called neutrinos emitted by the new NS heat the material and drive it out in a shock front through the surrounding star, generating a supernova explosion that delivers newly made elements into the interstellar medium of the galaxy.  A research team at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, will follow multidimensional computer simulations of the SiSB phase through the collapse/supernova phase in massive stars using state-of-the-art computational simulation codes to better understand this critical process for creating and dispersing atomic elements.  The PI will present public lectures on supernova science and nucleosynthesis, or element creation, and train a graduate student in both stellar astrophysics and large-scale computation.

The research team will simulate the developments in the last hour of convective silicon shell burning in a massive star and continue the simulations into the supernova explosion phase.  The team will run a multi-dimensional code with realistic microphysics, including nucleosynthesis, neutrino transport, and turbulent convection.  Since the code runs in three dimensions, they will be able to introduce asymmetries, which are known to be important, particularly for the supernova neutrino heating mechanism.  The pre-collapse burning models will explore the limits of dimensionality, spatial resolution, nuclear network completeness, and duration required to adequately capture this dynamic stellar phase.  The explosion simulations will calculate the element production from the supernova along with neutrino and gravitational wave signals.  The proposed work will use a simulation code called Chimera, which the PI describes as a combination of three separate mature codes covering three aspects of the problem.

por.por_cntn:
Massive stars (above about 10 times the mass of the sun) reach the end of their existence through a series of burning stages that convert lighter elements to heavier (oxygen to silicon to iron) at their centers until the iron core becomes to massive and collapses. The collapse of the iron core generates a supernova explosion that ejects some of those elements into interstellar space where they become incorporated into new stars and planets. The details of these explosions and the amounts of each element they eject are dependent on the size of the iron core and the structure of the layers above it.

When the core collapse is triggered there is a shell of silicon outside the iron core that grows the core as it burns. In the typical 1D stellar evolution codes used to compute the state of the star prior to collapse extra iron from silicon burning slowly accumulates on the surface and cools by emitting neutrinos until the iron core becomes too massive and collapses.

In our calculation we took the last 4.5 minutes of the pre-collapse silicon shell burning phase from one of these 1D models and recomputed it in 2D (axisymmetry) to allow convection in the silicon shell to develop. Because of the convection induced by the silicon burning, the shell became thoroughly mixed and remained hot without collapse until nearly all of the silicon in the shell had been converted to iron, before could cool and trigger the collapse.

The iron core in our model, where the full silicon shell had burned to iron, was about 0.1 solar masses larger than the collapsing iron core in the original 1D model, where only the inner half of the silicon shell had burned using the standard 1D approximations for convection. This difference is of the same magnitude of variations in the iron cores of collapsing stars seen from other effects.

Our results suggest that the collapsing iron cores of some massive stars might be moderately larger, particularly if collapse occurred while there was an actively burning silicon shell atop the iron core. They also imply requirements for initiation of core-collapse supernova calculations from massive stars and potentially a way to calibrate existing 1D pre-collapse stellar evolution treatments of convective silicon burning to improve those models as they have been improved for earlier shell burning stages through calibration relative to multidimensional models.
